events.target_title: xcb_xlib_threads_sequence_lost
Run GCMD as root not working in Ubuntu Mate 18.04

note.body:
You can launch the Gnome-Commander as root on Ubuntu 18.04 using the method mentioned by David Kohen.

Create the file /usr/share/polkit-1/actions/org.gnome.gnome-commander.policy

Copy/paste the following text to the new file:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE policyconfig PUBLIC
 "-//freedesktop//DTD PolicyKit Policy Configuration 1.0//EN"
 "http://www.freedesktop.org/standards/PolicyKit/1/policyconfig.dtd">
<policyconfig>

 <vendor>Gnome-Commander</vendor>
 <vendor_url>https://gcmd.github.io/</vendor_url>
 <icon_name>gnome-commander</icon_name>

 <action id="org.gnome.gnome-commander">
  <description>Gnome-Commander</description>
  <message>Authentication is required to run Gnome-Commander as root.</message>

  <defaults>
   <allow_any>no</allow_any>
   <allow_inactive>auth_admin</allow_inactive>
   <allow_active>auth_admin</allow_active>
  </defaults>

  <annotate key="org.freedesktop.policykit.exec.path">/usr/bin/gnome-commander</annotate>
  <annotate key="org.freedesktop.policykit.exec.allow_gui">true</annotate>
 </action>

</policyconfig>
```
Save the file and set file ownership and permissions to the same settings as existing files in the directory.

In your favorite text editor open /usr/share/applications/gnome-commander.desktop

Change the line:

	Exec=gnome-commander

To:

	Exec=pkexec gnome-commander

Save the file.  Now when you launch the Gnome-Commander you'll be prompted to enter a password.
Hope that helps.

Freeing brightness keys (XF86MonBrightnessUp and others) for custom handling via xbindkeys

note.body:
I'm going to go insane, and this will be on you, @bberg, I'm sorry to say... :wink: 

But allow me to give you my user story. On laptops, I have a habit of using Fn+cursor keys to do PgUp, PgDn, Home and End, because I use these keys a lot, and the default placement of these keys on laptops is usually inadequate.

So now that I bought a new laptop, which has them set up as Brightness Up, Brightness Down, Volume Up and Volume Down, trying to page up/down and ending up changing brightness instead was immediately infuriating.

I remapped them through `/etc/udev/hwdb.d`, like I did it the last few times, before I did anything else. Only, it didn't work: While the volume keys gave up and started doing what they were told immediately, the brightness keys now generate *both* a Page Up/Page Down keypress *and* a `XF86MonBrightnessUp`/`XF86MonBrightnessDown`.

After much investigation, I found the culprit: This being an MSI laptop, its Fn keys are quirky and some of them -- monitor brightness keys in particular -- generate ACPI events *in addition* to keyboard presses. 

Okay, I said, and added events in `/etc/acpid/events` to handle them by ignoring them, only... that didn't do anything.

After much *further* investigation, I found the answer in `acpi_video.c` in the depths of kernel sources: The acpi event is acted upon well before it gets into the userland, and a faux keypress KEY_BRIGHTNESSUP is injected into an input device. I can't remap that one through hwdb because it's false in the first place, and that's how it leaks out into userland. And naturally, the kernel module has no option not to do that.

Okay, I said, and went trying to figure out what happens to the offending keypress after that. After all, out of X, my newly remapped keys are just page up and page down, no brightness changes occur. Surely I should be able to stop Gnome from acting upon them?

...And now you're telling me I can't, because I live in a corner case, so I'll have to either patch a kernel driver or gsd-media-keys, and I'm not even sure which is worse. :frowning2:

events.target_title: Freeing brightness keys (XF86MonBrightnessUp and others) for custom handling via xbindkeys

note.body:
Sorry if I wasn't clear enough, but it does seem you didn't quite read it correctly. Let me reiterate.

1. I *did* remap the brightness keys with hwdb. That succeeded. The keys -- the actual Fn+cursor keys -- send the keycodes I want.
2. But this particular laptop sends an ACPI event *in addition to* the keypress that gets remapped, for whatever mysterious reason. This does not get remapped by hwdb, and now coexists in parallel with a remapped key.
3. Well before it gets into the userland to be handled by `acpid`, where I could intercept it, this ACPI event gets processed by `acpi_video.c` in the kernel. That generates an input event on a different input device -- which *can't* be remapped by hwdb. Apparently, because it's not the result of an actual keypress. I did try a considerable number of times, but if by whatever chance I am wrong, I would very much like to be enlightened. [See acpi_video.c](https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/drivers/acpi/acpi_video.c#L1633)
4. It turns out that it's this event that eventually triggers Gnome to change the brightness when I am pressing what is otherwise a PgUp/PgDn key as far as the rest of the system is concerned.
5. Having an input event I can't remap at hwdb level, I have no choice but try to remap it at X level. Nothing I tried worked to do that, until I stumbled on this issue.

I eventually did manage to recompile `gnome-settings-daemon` with two lines commented out which at least got me to the state where I can keep working *(or seeking a better solution)* without looking to break something, so there's that.

In any case, I'm very happy to hear that in the future I'll have an easier way out by simply reassigning these X keys to run a placeholder instead. Up until that gets into Ubuntu I'll just have to cope, I suppose... Thank you.

events.target_title: Freeing brightness keys (XF86MonBrightnessUp and others) for custom handling via xbindkeys

note.body:
Indeed, `acpid` is not used, though I found that out the hard way. I didn't say otherwise, did I? But an ACPI event results in the kernel *generating* a keypress event that does not correspond to an actual key, and *that* is the keypress that hwdb cannot trap that triggers gnome.

And yes, I used `evemu-describe` a lot. Didn't help.

events.target_title: Freeing brightness keys (XF86MonBrightnessUp and others) for custom handling via xbindkeys

note.body:
While I agree that my problem is exotic, and mostly exists because of my obsessive habits when other people would just retrain, I would appreciate if you did not immediately assume incompetence is the cause.

```
evdev:atkbd:dmi:bvn*:bvr*:bd*:svnMicro*:pnGE63Raider*
 KEYBOARD_KEY_f8=pageup
 KEYBOARD_KEY_f7=pagedown
 KEYBOARD_KEY_ae=home
 KEYBOARD_KEY_b0=end
```

You really can't get more complete than that -- four scancodes, four keys. As you can see, it works as written:

```
Event: time 1552044493.487432, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1552044496.798966, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value f8
Event: time 1552044496.798966, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 104 (KEY_PAGEUP), value 1
Event: time 1552044496.798966, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
^[[5~Event: time 1552044496.911794, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value f8
Event: time 1552044496.911794, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 104 (KEY_PAGEUP), value 0
Event: time 1552044496.911794, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1552044497.733991, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value f7
Event: time 1552044497.733991, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 109 (KEY_PAGEDOWN), value 1
Event: time 1552044497.733991, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
^[[6~Event: time 1552044497.824946, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value f7
Event: time 1552044497.824946, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 109 (KEY_PAGEDOWN), value 0
Event: time 1552044497.824946, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1552044498.886881, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value ae
Event: time 1552044498.886881, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 102 (KEY_HOME), value 1
Event: time 1552044498.886881, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
^[[HEvent: time 1552044498.979162, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value ae
Event: time 1552044498.979162, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 102 (KEY_HOME), value 0
Event: time 1552044498.979162, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1552044499.508214, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value b0
Event: time 1552044499.508214, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 107 (KEY_END), value 1
Event: time 1552044499.508214, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
^[[FEvent: time 1552044499.599963, type 4 (EV_MSC), code 4 (MSC_SCAN), value b0
Event: time 1552044499.599963, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 107 (KEY_END), value 0
```

But the brightness keys are not actually gone. These keys *also* result in ACPI events, observable with `acpi_listen`:

```
video/brightnessup BRTUP 00000086 00000000
video/brightnessdown BRTDN 00000087 00000000
```

Those ACPI event are processed in `acpi_video.c`, part of the `video` module, that controls the backlight itself. Then the module writes directly into *another* input device. Here's what that one says:

```
Select the device event number [0-17]: 14
Input driver version is 1.0.1
Input device ID: bus 0x19 vendor 0x0 product 0x6 version 0x0
Input device name: "Video Bus"
Supported events:
  Event type 0 (EV_SYN)
  Event type 1 (EV_KEY)
    Event code 224 (KEY_BRIGHTNESSDOWN)
    Event code 225 (KEY_BRIGHTNESSUP)
    Event code 227 (KEY_SWITCHVIDEOMODE)
    Event code 241 (KEY_VIDEO_NEXT)
    Event code 242 (KEY_VIDEO_PREV)
    Event code 243 (KEY_BRIGHTNESS_CYCLE)
    Event code 244 (KEY_BRIGHTNESS_ZERO)
    Event code 245 (KEY_DISPLAY_OFF)
Properties:
Testing ... (interrupt to exit)
^[[5~Event: time 1552044607.991531, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 225 (KEY_BRIGHTNESSUP), value 1
Event: time 1552044607.991531, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1552044607.991538, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 225 (KEY_BRIGHTNESSUP), value 0
Event: time 1552044607.991538, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
^[[6~Event: time 1552044608.663731, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 224 (KEY_BRIGHTNESSDOWN), value 1
Event: time 1552044608.663731, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
Event: time 1552044608.663743, type 1 (EV_KEY), code 224 (KEY_BRIGHTNESSDOWN), value 0
Event: time 1552044608.663743, -------------- SYN_REPORT ------------
```

There they are. Let's try plugging them with `acpid` before they become keypresses:

```
# Argh.
event=video/brightnessdown
action=<drop>
```

No dice: They no longer show up on `acpi_listen` after that, but the keystrokes on the "Video Bus" input device remain. It took me a while to trace the path they take through the system, and grepping the kernel sources is what brought me to the `video` module that I cited a few posts ago. This kernel module processes these ACPI events and generates input events from them well before `acpid` ever comes into play.

So I should be able to remap the keystrokes themselves, right? But as you can see above, there's no `MSC_SCAN` event at all, they're key up/down events without an originating scancode. I don't know a way to get hwdb to remap that, but if you do, I would dearly love to know.

To sum it up, remapping the brightness keys using hwdb is perfectly viable and worked first try. But what causes my problem is not keys themselves, but the kernel writing scancode-less events *directly* into a `/dev/input`, which produces spurious keys I can't get rid of by conventional means.

Patching gnome-settings-daemon to ignore them was easier than patching the kernel to not send them, in the end, and unless there's a method to intercept them before they get to gnome-settings-daemon, that's the solution I'm going to have to use.

note.body:
I use three IMAP accounts. Each has tens of folders holding mailing lists (whole mail is filtered server side). So my new mails can be present in any folder.

While I use Thunderbird I usually switch to 'show me folder with unread email' folderview to see which mailing lists have new mails. Choose one, read some mails, skip other, some mark as read. Pressing 'n' key moves me from folder to folder so going through emails does not require reconfiguration of mail client. In Evolution I have to remember when to press spacebar to jump new folder or reach for mouse to change folder by hand (or use folder search function).


You suggest to use 'search folders'. I looked at that and there is no way to mark 'show me just unread mails' - 'Status' condition lists 'Replied To, Draft, Important, Read, or Junk' only. And even if it would then I would need to replicate existing folder structure just to get same trees of mailing list folders for unread mails.

I do not know, maybe a way to read mails got changed in recent years. I used Sylpheed, Claws, Evolution (gnome 1/2 times), KMail, Thunderbird and probably few other mail clients. Each time had one tree of folders (with few mail accounts) with filtered mails and was going "folder with unread mails" by "folder with unread mails" when had time to deal with mail.

events.target_title: Provide fsck functionality
Provide fsck functionality

note.body:
The filesystem check option doesn't appear for any disk, even as a disabled item, in the two systems based on Ubuntu 14.04 (udisks2-2.1.3) and 16.04 (udisks-2.1.7) LTS. On the 16.04 system I can install gnome-disk-utility-3.32 with the same result.

There's a leap to the next supported version of udisks2 (2.7.6) and dependency hell makes installing this equivalent to an OS upgrade.

Did this really not work in 2016 or 2014 or earlier? Apparently so, as I now realise that gnome-disk-utility should really have been called gnome-udisksctl and udisks-2.7.2 or later is needed for the Check method of the org.freedesktop.UDisks2.Filesystem interface.

It is X (not Wayland).

In the inspector, there is a GtkSettings object and the gtk-cursor-blink is set to TRUE. When I change it to FALSE, the caret stops blinking.

I should note that Gedit is reading the configuration file `.config/gtk-3.0/settings.ini`, according to my strace experiment as reported in #2222, and so is `gsd-xsettings`.

Thank you Andre, and thanks Matthias for teaching me about the inspector.

events.target_title: "gtk-cursor-blink = false" in .config/gtk-3.0/settings.ini not respected

note.body:
Thanks for the information about xsettings taking priority. I noticed that if I kill the settings daemon then my file-based configuration takes effect and the cursor does not blink.

I am not sure why a user would put something like this in a file and not want it to take priority, is that behavior intentional?

When I run

    gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.interface cursor-blink false

then I can get desired behavior in gedit even with the daemon running. I think someone must have told me this command before, since I found it in a document that I contributed to. Should we update the [documentation link you provided](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/3.24/GtkSettings.html#GtkSettings--gtk-cursor-blink) to tell users how to set the various settings using a command like `gsettings` invocation? I noticed that it does say that `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/gtk-3.0` is only read if the settings daemon is running, but it's weird to find this information after pages of what looks like a C API specification. In any case, I apologize for not reading the fine print. I would expect this kind of thing to be in a manual page however.

I believe that the settings daemon I was running is `gsd-xsettings` - it starts and stays open if I run it after killing the other process. There are only a couple of error messages, as shown above.

Thanks again.

note.body: That may be, but from what I can see the only time `this._userProxy` is accessed is if `XDG_SESSION_ID` isn't set and that's only now happening as the referenced commit causes it to be unset. I just tried 3.34.2 again having remove `XDG_SESSION_ID` from the blacklist (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-session/blob/60e619b8a2cacc7b844fe6f0e206c895de68f890/gnome-session/gsm-util.c#L47) and gdm works again.

events.target_title: gnome-session 3.34.2 breaking GNOME w/o systemd

note.body: This may be a bug in `elogind`. Ultimately, that dbus message is received and results in a call to `cg_path_get_owner_uid` (https://github.com/elogind/elogind/blob/v241-stable/src/basic/cgroup-util.c#L1818) which does a `read_one_line_file` on, eg, `/run/systemd/sessions/c2`, the first line of which is `# This is private data. Do not parse.` which, unsurprisingly, doesn't resolve to a valid uid in `parse_uid` so an error is returned: `Caller does not belong to any logged in user or lingering user`

events.target_title: Don't delete played episodes

note.body:
I do like thinking of this functionality as an archive so I will refer to it as such for this post. 

> Are there other use cases (other than the paywall thing)?

There are some other scenarios where an archive feature could come in handy.

One that comes immediately to mind is that podcasts come and go. Having an archive is the only way one can listen to previous episodes if the feed and servers are taken offline. 

Another scenario where such a feature would be convenient is referencing information from previous episodes. I participate in several history discussion groups and people will sometimes ask questions about topics that I felt were well covered on an old episode of a podcast. When this happens, I like to provide them with the podcast, episode number, and a timestamp of where the pertinent information begins. It's more convenient in this scenario to have the episode already stored on my system rather than having to download it again. Admittedly, I have no idea how niche this scenario is. 

The last scenario that comes to mind at the moment is probably quite niche. Due to the nature of my work I sometimes find myself in places with spotty or non-existent Internet connectivity. When the work doesn't require a great deal of concentration, I like to listen to podcasts. However, because I periodically have to focus all of my attention on a task at hand, I prefer to listen to episodes that I've previously finished. Because of the lack of Internet connectivity, having an archive readily available is very convenient. 

* Would archived episodes be part of the queue? I'd guess not, so the "just download automatically if it's in the queue" abstraction wouldn't apply.

* Would there be an "Archive" section for things saved offline but not in the queue?

I think it would make sense to have archived episodes in a separate section.

I have two rough ideas of how an interface for an archive feature could be implemented. 

My first idea would be to utilize the existing Shows tab. With this method I imagine either having two lists of episodes, one for new and in progress episodes (the current list) and another list for archived episodes  (perhaps appearing under the first list). A different take on this idea, but one that wouldn't completely separate archived episodes from the current queue, could be to maintain the single list that currently exists but marking archived episodes. So there would be a single list with episodes listed in order but with an icon or some other method that indicates the user has finished the episode and chosen not to remove it. In either case, I don't believe it would make sense for archived episodes to appear under the New tab. 

My second idea is to add an Archive tab next to New and Shows tabs. With this method I imagine the Archive tab functioning very similarly to the Shows tab where clicking on a show gives you a list of archived episodes. One downside of this method that comes to mind is that without some kind of distinction between the Shows and Archive tab, it would be easy for users to mistakenly think they were on one rather than the other. One potential way to alleviate this would be to apply a filter (a black and white filter for example) or add an overlay icon (say a picture of the commonly used archive box to the corner) to the show images under the Archive tab.

> How would you add an episode to the archive?

Three ideas come to mind.

My first idea would be to include a setting in the preferences. For example, there could be an entry under Appearances titled Archive Old Episodes that includes a switch. When enabled, the Delete played episodes option could be grayed out or hidden. 

My second idea, although probably more difficult for users to discover, would be to include an archive button under a show's hamburger menu. For example, under the Mark All as Played option that already exists a menu item could be added titled Archive Episodes. When clicked, this could cause the Podcasts application to archive episodes for that show specifically (this would give the users more granular control since they wouldn't have to choose between archive every show or no shows). Moreover, when a show is set to be archived, the hamburger menu item could change to Stop Archiving Episodes so the user could stop archiving episodes of the show if they desired. 

My third idea, which would give the most granular control, would be to include an archive button next to the play button that exists in each episode's list entry. With this method when the user clicks an episode's archive button, the episode wouldn't be automatically deleted after the user has finished listening to it. 

> Would/Should you be able to import/export the archived episodes?

Part of me doesn't think that a separate export feature would be necessary because a user could copy out the files from Podcast's data directory (which is what I currently do to backup shows I don't want automatically deleted when I finish listening to them). On the other hand that isn't intuitive and a user very well may want to export archived shows so they could import them on another machine, which is why the other part of me thinks an export feature may be useful. 

As for importing archives, that could be something that is handled by the current Import Shows option. If a user imports a show, whether it's one they archived on another machine or not, it could be treated as a normal show. If the archive functionality isn't applied to every episode, this would require the user to set the imported show's archive option to prevent episodes from being removed.

GTK application launched in Xorg session connects to a Wayland server instead

note.body:
I don't think waxing on about lofty idealism is going to solve the problem.

I think that libwayland was wrong to guess `wayland-0` if `WAYLAND_DISPLAY` is unset, but fixing that probably isn't going to happen for backwards compatibility reasons. Therefore, I think the Right Thing to do is to prepare a list of suitable backends based on what environment variables are set - such as `DISPLAY` or `WAYLAND_DISPLAY`, or based other information for backends where environment variables are not appropriate. If `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` would prefer a particular backend, use it if possible and abort if not. If `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` does not express such a preference, then the backends should be prioritized and the most suitable one used first - Wayland, then X11.

For GTK's purposes, `GDK_BACKEND` should probably be given priority over `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` if set, and have similar behavior - use the requested backend if suitable, and abort if not.

Note that `XDG_SESSION_TYPE`, as far as I can tell, is not described by any standard. I'm not opposed to establishing one. However, this may be justification for disregarding it entirely as well. The current behavior of most sessions which are started without a login manager* will have `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` unset on non-logind systems, and set to `tty` on logind systems. This presents a problem for sway et al, because it's clearly not our responsibility to set `XDG_SESSION_TYPE` (that would fall upon the login manager), but logind has this annoying behavior of exporting it as `tty`, which is wrong once the Wayland session begins. These weird inconsistencies come from the fact that the variable, its possible values, who sets it and when, and what applications should do with it - was never discussed or formalized.

\* If someone says "well you should be using a login manager anyway", it's going to start a flame war that we probably don't need to have.

note.body:
Useful comments, thank you.  Actually, on reflection, I'm being overly negative about the idea of a registry. In that context one option might be:

Leave the metadata interface as-is but also have a standard metadata object as part of Gegl.  The metadata object implements a registry for format conversions and presents an application-facing API using metadata names "blessed" by Gegl (and declared using GeglParamSpec so UI generation, i18n etc is easy). PNG seems to have the most well defined metadata names so that might be a good starting point. A couple of methods could be added to the interface for the file loaders/savers to register mappings for the file format.

Using the above approach, it would be trivial to implement the file-format converter - create the metadata object, pass it to the loader then pass to the saver, possibly doing some image transforms and metadata edits in-between.

While this should cover the majority of use-cases, an application can always implement its own objects supporting GeglMetadata to handle unusual or specialised cases.

I realised too that I make the application tell the metadata object what the file format is.  This, of course, should be registered by the file loader/saver.

I'll give this a bit more thought, it shouldn't be too hard to implement something like this.

events.target_title: Proposal: load and save image file metadata

note.body:
Folowing on from the above use-case a metadata store is created implementing the GeglMetadata interface. The attached example is a first draft of how this might look. The examples attached are based on working code and currently compile but are untested. For now it should be taken as an illustration of intent.
# Overview
Gegl defines a number of standard metadata variables.  For consistency with other GObject features, the naming convention is the same as for GObject properties, ie lower case letters, digits and hyphens and starting with a letter. If metadata variables are mapped to properties, underscores and hyphens are equivalent, however underscores are strongly discouraged.

Each metadata variable has a corresponding GType, typically this is G_TYPE_STRING, however other types may be appropriate in certain cases, eg G_TYPE_DATE_TIME would be appropriate for timestamps.

GeglMetadata is provided to interface file modules to the metadata subsystem.  A standard GeglMetadataStore object is provided, however any object implementing the GeglMetadata interface can interoperate with the file modules.

GeglMetadata *does not* provide an application interface to the metadata subsystem, this is left to specific object implementations.

## GeglMetadata
File load / store modules use the GeglMetadata interface to:

* register names specific to the file format and map them to the corresponding Gegl names
* specify type conversions where required (eg. timestamps from file format to GDateTime)
* iterate available metadata variables using names specific to the file format
* lookup specific metadata variables using names specific to the file format
* get or set metadata variables
* get or set image resolution

Type conversions are specific to the file format, for example, some files use RFC 1123 strings for timestamps, others might require ISO 8601, yet others may be arbitrary.

The GEGL_MAP_EXCLUDE_UNMAPPED flag to `gegl_metadata_store_register_map()` indicates that the underlying file format or library cannot accept metadata values other than those declared by the file module. For example, although TIFF is an easily extended file format, libtiff must be modified to accept new tags or IFDs therefore the TIFF file modules should set this flag.  Objects implementing GeglMetadata should respect this flag, for example allowing the application to modify an existing metadata mapping but refusing additional mappings.

Any object implementing GeglMetadata will interoperate with the file modules.

## GeglMetadataStore
An object providing an API for metadata access using standard Gegl names.

Standard Gegl metadata variables are declared using GParamSpecs. Only declared values may be assigned or read.

Values are stored in a hash table of GValues where the key is the variable name. When metadata variables are set GeglMetadataStore emits a `"changed"` signal analogous to the GObject `"notify"` signal. The detail parameter is the GQuark of the variable name.

Methods are provided allowing the application to test whether a particular metadata item has a value and to set or get the values.  As implemented if a metadata value does not exist, a GLib warning is printed. The `gegl_metadata_store_has_value()` method can be used to test silently for unset variables.

Image resolution and resolution units are accessible as properties.

Certain metatdata variables are shadowed by properties to take advantage of features such as introspection and property binding. (is this overkill?)

GeglMetadataStore implements the GeglMetadata interface with the following features:

* after the file modules registers the metadata name map, GeglMetadataStore emits a `"mapped"` signal giving the application an opportunity to register additional mappings. An argument to the signal specifies the file format implemented by the module.
* the GeglMetadata iterator iterates the registered set of mappings including those supplied by the application. Unmapped but otherwise valid metadata variables are silently ignored.
* if the file module looks up an unknown metadata name GeglMetadataStore emits an `"unmapped"` signal allowing the application to create a mapping on the fly, if required.

### Notes
It would be trivial to extend the metadata store with methods so the application can iterate the full set of metadata and associated GParamSpecs (i.e. using the standard Gegl names) allowing, for example, a UI to be constructed on-the-fly.

An application can use the `"mapped"` or `"unmapped"` signals to create or overload metadata variables thus providing additional features.  For example, the TIFF `ImageDescription` tag could be overloaded to write out the usual description metadata variable followed by a marker and unmapped variables in an application-specific format, say, Json.

## Use case for GeglMetadataStore
An application implements a simple file format converter as follows:
* create a GeglMetadataStore object
* pass it to a file loader - when loaded the GeglBuffer is available and the GeglMetadataStore is loaded
* pass the GeglBuffer and GeglMetadataStore to a file saver

The application has no interaction with the GeglMetadataStore other than creating and destroying it and passing it to the file modules. 

Only metadata variables known to both the loader and saver are copied across. Image resolution is guaranteed to be copied and scaled, if necessary, correctly.

Here 'known' means the variables registered by the file modules. Unknown values are silently ignored either by the loader or saver. If saving back to the same file format, non-standard metadata values are dropped; for example, PNG permits any string as a variable name but the standard specifies only a small number of variables. The non-standard variables will be lost in this scenario.

A more advanced application could use the `"mapped"` and `"unmapped"` signals to transfer additional metadata values. However to do so reliably may require knowledge of how third-party applications make use of custom metadata and may require sophisticated parsers and formatters to do so.

[gegl-metadatastore.h](/uploads/c92954aa45f1397820ba32fcf0e571ce/gegl-metadatastore.h)

[gegl-metadata.h](/uploads/b5d470c7f228d4e1b5e9a2a9c0e11a77/gegl-metadata.h)

[gegl-metadatastore.c](/uploads/de4f1f30768e221b5b53b1a216f8c76b/gegl-metadatastore.c)

[gegl-metadata.c](/uploads/bf985fe6da31749f3e77bec3ed25bc73/gegl-metadata.c)

note.body:
On 3/15/19 12:20 AM, Ondrej Holy wrote:
> Ondrej Holy <https://gitlab.gnome.org/oholy commented:
>     Don't know. My new phone is the first MTP device I have used.
> 
> Nevermind, but just a note, that this should not be strictly related to  MTP, but also for many other locations provided by GVfs. Can you please try the following to be sure it is not related to MTP?

Certainly!

> |$ gio mount localtest:/// $ ls /run/user/500/gvfs/ localtest:|

Reproduced:

```
$ gio mount localtest:///
$ ls /run/user/500/gvfs/
localtest:
```

I don't know if this means anything, but localtest: show the root of my hard drive (IAmNVMe was put there by me to tell it apart from a swap-in mechanical drive).

```
$ ls /run/user/500/gvfs/localtest\:
bin   dev  home     lib    lin-bak     media  opt   root  sbin  sys  usr
boot  etc  IAmNVMe  lib64  lost+found  mnt    proc  run   srv   tmp  var
```

> The reason you see |fuse: bad mount point| is because |pkill gvfsd-fuse fusermount -u /run/user/500/gvfs| is not one command, but two.
> 
> |$ pkill gvfsd-fuse $ fusermount -u /run/user/500/gvfs|
> 
> Please try again...

That was probably a formatting error on the web site.  It has the
annoying habit of removing my line feeds.
```
$  pkill gvfsd-fuse
$ fusermount -u /run/user/500/gvfs
fusermount: entry for /run/user/500/gvfs not found in /etc/mtab
```

Thank you for all the help with this!

It works fine without it, and it allows the "remember me" box to come up, which doesn't happen with this parameter.
Other applications like davmail are not sending it either.

events.target_title: Simplify OAuth2 for outlook.office365.com server

note.body:
This parameter breaks using evolution-ews to connect to office365. Without this, as mentioned, it works fine. Davmail is not using it either and it works out of the box: https://github.com/mguessan/davmail/blob/master/src/java/davmail/exchange/auth/O365InteractiveAuthenticator.java#L94

As mentioned in the commit message, because of this parameter the login server returns the following error:

```
    eos_office365_extract_authorization_code:
      error:invalid_request description:AADSTS65002:
      Consent between first party applications and resources must be
      configured via preauthorization.
```

events.target_title: Simplify OAuth2 for outlook.office365.com server

note.body:
Thanks for the review! Responses inline.

Regarding the tenant, it might not work everywhere, but neither does the default URL redirect field, and yet it does have a default :-) So I think having a default with a chance of working, and letting users override it, makes sense for user-friendliness. This is what other EWS applications do - in fact, davmail just hard-codes "common" and doesn't allow overrides at all.

As far as I understand, "common" will work for any users that authenticate against Azure AD. It's only full-on-prem deployments that need to override it. I think...

note.body:
Hey.
As the new maintainer of libravatar, I'd love to see you switch.
The code is stable and heavily used by git.kernel.org.
The infrastructure is provided by Fedora Project.
I think it's save to switch to libravatar and if you encounter any issues, please get in contact with me (mail, irc or any other way...).

events.target_title: Replace Gravatar support by a more privacy aware tool
Replace Gravatar support by a more privacy aware tool

note.body:
@tobiasmue You mean you are concerned that Libravatar knows that some user is surfing gitlab.gnome.org? We take privacy serious! 
If you don't want to trust Libravatar you can still create a small script to proxy the request on your side to Libravatar. This means the request would come from the GitLab instance and Libravatar wouldn't know who the _user_ is. Only which hashes are accessed.

events.target_title: [Wayland] gtk_window_present() not working

note.body:
Just adding a data point here (and a question): I heavily rely on the command line for git etc, and I use geany as my editor. Under X11, I can open files in a running instance of geany just by invoking it from the command line. Under Wayland, this no longer works, and I have to Alt-Tab my way around my workspaces to find it.

Up until now, I had assumed that this was a bug that was in the process of being fixed. But if I understand @ebassi correctly, this is actually working as intended, and it is the window manager that stipulates that no application launched from a terminal shall ever grab the focus automatically.

If this is the case, is this documented anywhere? Is there a policy that describes this? Or is it the personal view of a single developer who happens to be in control of this particular behavior?

events.target_title: [Wayland] gtk_window_present() not working

note.body:
Pardon my ignorance - I guess the timestamp is intended to mitigate the delayed focus switch when launching a slow loading app from the terminal?

In any case, even though you claim this behavior has been the default for 15 years, it breaks my workflow when I switch from X11 to Wayland. So default behavior or not, X11 and Wayland definitely implement it in different ways, and I'd like to understand why Wayland's interpretation is the correct one.

Solution:

kill gnome-weather

.cache/libgweather folder delete

Dconf editor open `org/gnome/weather/` reset settings

Ready. But this is a temporary solution

note.body:
Hi,
Here is my code:

```
#include <stdio.h>
#include <geocode-glib/geocode-glib.h>
#include <gio/gio.h>

void callback (GObject *source_object, GAsyncResult *res, gpointer user_data) {
   printf("tata\n");
   return;
}

int main(int argc, char** argv)
{
   GMainLoop *loop;
   GeocodeForward  *test;

   printf("toto %s\n", argv[1]);

   test = geocode_forward_new_for_string (argv[1]);

   geocode_forward_search_async (test, NULL, callback, NULL);

   loop = g_main_loop_new ( NULL , FALSE );
   g_main_loop_run (loop);
   g_main_loop_unref(loop);

   return 0;
}
```


Build :
`gcc -o geocode geocode.c -g $( pkg-config  libecal-1.2 --libs --cflags ) $( pkg-config geocode-glib-1.0 --libs --cflags )`

Launch :
```
#./greocode "Europe"
toto Europe
Erreur de segmentation (core dumped)
```

note.body:
I'm hitting problems with GIO using a trash folder on an NFS mount using systemd automount. The problems seem similar to some of the problems described in this issue. Permissions are correct with respect to a trash folder in `/mnt/media/.Trash` per the FreeDesktop trash spec:

```
Python 2.7.15 (default, Jan 10 2019, 23:20:52) 
[GCC 8.2.1 20181127] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from gi.repository import GObject, Gio
>>> f = Gio.File.new_for_path('/mnt/media/foo.txt')
>>> f.trash(cancellable=None)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
gi.repository.GLib.Error: g-io-error-quark: Trashing on system internal mounts is not supported (15)
>>> 
```

`/mnt/media` is configured in `/etc/fstab` as:

```
freenas:/mnt/tank/media	/mnt/media	nfs noatime,x-systemd.automount,x-systemd.requires=network-online.target,x-systemd.idle-timeout=60min	0 0
```

and `/proc/mounts` shows:

```
$ cat /proc/mounts | grep media
systemd-1 /mnt/media autofs rw,relatime,fd=92,pgrp=1,timeout=3600,minproto=5,maxproto=5,direct,pipe_ino=21177 0 0

freenas:/mnt/tank/media /mnt/media nfs rw,noatime,vers=3,rsize=131072,wsize=131072,namlen=255,hard,proto=tcp,timeo=600,retrans=2,sec=sys,mountaddr=192.168.2.202,mountvers=3,mountport=727,mountproto=udp,local_lock=none,addr=192.168.2.202 0 0
```

events.target_title: Too much information in File Systems

note.body:
It turns out the solution was to completely remove Snap and its configuration, and reinstall the packages the classic way. My shortcuts still work and the File Systems is usable again.
```
# uninstall snap and reinstall packages the classic way
sudo apt purge snapd
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install gnome-calculator gnome-characters gnome-logs gnome-system-monitor
```
**File Systems in Ubuntu 18.04 without Snap**
![File-Systems-in-Ubuntu-18.04-no-snap](/uploads/d81dd9102fd87a53af8cb2ea6685373e/File-Systems-in-Ubuntu-18.04-no-snap.png)

**`df -h`, no Snap**

events.target_title: Make the Dash visible when no window touching it

note.body:
I am sorry for arguing with you, since I totally respect your contribution to the GNOME project, but your reaction to this issue as a maintainer is unfit.

I think it is clear that author asked to add a one-click launcher. First let's figure it out if the requested functionality fits into GNOME purpose. The projects README says:

>  GNOME Shell provides core user interface functions for the GNOME 3 desktop, like switching to windows and launching applications.

So, the requested functionality is in line with stated primary purpose of this project. Now let's compare it to the current implementation. Since the requested functionality is mouse-based, I will compare it to current mouse-based implementation. Currently user have to do the following:

1.  Navigate mouse to top-left corner with specific speed.
2.  Wait until Activities overview is animated and displayed. 
3.  Navigate mouse to desired application icon.
4.  Click.

Alternatively:

1.  Navigate mouse to top-left corner.
2.  Click.
3.  Wait until Activities overview is animated and displayed. 
4.  Navigate mouse to desired application icon.
5.  Click.

Note that when the specific speed from method 1 is not achieved, but user intended to open the Activities with method 1, they get no indication of failed attempt. Instead it is reasonable for the user to think that heavy animation will soon start, and they should wait for it. As a result the user spares time and gets annoyed.

Another scenario is when the required speed is achieved, but the animation didn't start immediately. User can think that method 1 failed and they decide to try method 2 and click. Then the animation begins. But the user has already made a decision to click, which they cannot cancel, since humans cannot react to stimuli that fast. So the click closes Activities. And again, the user spares time and gets annoyed.

Now lets analyse the requested behavior.

1.  Navigate mouse to desired application icon.
2.  Click.

No time wasting, no heavy operations and the experience is straightforward. I think the proposed UX is clearly superior to the current one.

If the reason of not adding one-click functionality is "It doesn't fit on a smartwatch", then there clearly is an architectural problem in GNOME shell. It should be split then into basic abstract shell providing some API, and its extensions. Like GNOME Desktop, GNOME Tablet, GNOME Phone, GNOME Auto, whatever. If you say that one GNOME shell should be fit for different screen sizes like in utopic Convergence, then this is the wrong way. Better have different extensions from different developers for different screen sizes and shapes.
